channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: It's important to adjust your workouts when you hit 50. Here are some exercises to help keep you strong and safe into the decades to come. https://t.co/JQxy0SWdHF

Yellowstone celebrates its 150th anniversary on March 1. See how America's first national park paved the way for others across the U.S., and what’s in store to preserve its future. https://t.co/FqujWdUIlu

“We won’t retreat or surrender.” In the battle for Kviv, Russian troops are facing not only Ukrainian armed forces but also thousands of civilians, including a pizzeria owner and a political consultant. https://t.co/Ux5xE2Z9H2

Russian President Vladimir Putin says Volodymyr Zelensky and others in Ukraine’s government are nationalists and neo-Nazis—the latest emotive epithets the Kremlin has deployed to justify invading the country https://t.co/zNep8UU1Po
Twitter said its service was being limited in Russia and that it is trying to keep the platform accessible to users https://t.co/tUJpk1Xolc

Germany has allowed the Netherlands to deliver German-made weapons to Ukraine, breaking with its strict refusal to authorize the delivery of lethal weapons to the country, government officials said https://t.co/Zhvy7ogJmA
Russian state-controlled media have sought to advance Putin’s narrative that Ukraine is an aggressor that threatens Russia https://t.co/9P8XSdkuQr
Ukraine’s embassy to the Czech Republic launched a crowdfunding campaign to raise funds for weapon purchases for Ukraine’s armed forces fighting the Russian invasion https://t.co/5d3w1UK9lx

An SEC investigation into Tesla stock sales by Elon Musk and his brother Kimbal is partly focused on trades Kimbal made ahead of Elon’s decision to sell based on a Twitter poll #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/gyqiaLppsj https://t.co/QL6FrHuhXG
Western countries weighing how to sanction Russia over the invasion of Ukraine are up against the reality of its grip over Europe’s energy supply https://t.co/ycGi73woLj
European Union officials said there was growing momentum to cut Russia out of Swift, a crucial global payments system https://t.co/9104Dg43O0
A 500-pound black bear was accused of breaking into more than two dozen South Lake Tahoe homes. But “Hank the Tank” isn’t the criminal he was made out to be. https://t.co/DoYGWS5531

The crisis in Ukraine has united most Republicans around the argument that President Biden has been too weak. Beyond that, the party is still working to define a foreign-policy agenda. https://t.co/4PTYsjZTN1

U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken says $350 million in military aid will include further lethal defensive assistance for Ukraine. The announcement for aid follows an appeal from Ukraine for support. https://t.co/5LVD0DKPeX
Russia has used a variety of hacks and misinformation tactics to destabilize and disrupt Ukraine. Here’s a look at the different types of cyberattacks. https://t.co/RUO0igMz0g
Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has returned war to Europe. Western officials are smarting over how they misread Putin’s intentions. “It was strategic narcissism.” https://t.co/i3VeR1AnTV
Street battles raged through the night in the Ukrainian capital as Russian forces and undercover units in civilian clothes tried to enter the city https://t.co/wTxmPK7YWq
Take a look at the front page of today's Wall Street Journal https://t.co/x1ZpsyTghJ https://t.co/XWocs1ijj2

Hong Kong’s leader, Carrie Lam, was summoned to a meeting on the mainland where she got a direct order sent from Xi Jinping: Get the outbreak under control ahead of planned visit by the Chinese president's to the city https://t.co/YBsnoYAbdt
First it was Georgia, then Crimea, then Eastern Ukraine. So why was the West so surprised when Putin started marching on Kyiv? https://t.co/D8tUGgrDsR
Street battles raged through the night in the Ukrainian capital as Russian forces and undercover units in civilian clothes tried to enter the city https://t.co/JhkY3yiy8E
Russia’s invasion of Ukraine aims to overthrow the leadership in Kyiv, but President Volodymyr Zelensky remains defiant https://t.co/kWCzOHgL2d
China’s leader Xi Jinping called on Russian President Vladimir Putin to negotiate with Ukraine, the most recent twist as Beijing modulates its embrace of Russia https://t.co/4DLmEkWHC2

From @WSJopinion: The U.S. remains the world’s indispensable power and retains global interests, write @robertcobrien and Alexander B. Gray. To deter Russia and China, the Biden administration must act now. https://t.co/Au0gfsME3D
“The fate of Ukraine is being decided right now," President Volodymyr Zelensky said late Friday night. https://t.co/8vDdeXdjFg
Here is an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal's weekend edition https://t.co/cqhUrMrdtL https://t.co/GjWmOTEzXO
From @WSJopinion: Leaders understand what’s at stake in the Ukraine conflict but are in denial about what a solution requires of them, writes @josephsternberg https://t.co/lQpwdwuHZs

What the U.S. and Europe got wrong about Putin: “The West may have underestimated the Kremlin’s willingness to use force in Europe, and against a people which Putin claims are one with Russians.” https://t.co/HOAimJcBwU

Ukrainians fleeing the Russian invasion began streaming Friday into European Union nations, in what neighboring countries expect to become an exodus of more than one million people in the coming days https://t.co/s2yXw51vSg
The West is grappling with how to respond to Russia’s violent assault on Ukraine. The U.S. is considering its next steps. https://t.co/HJpQuTygw9

From @WSJopinion: Vladimir Putin has claimed his place in history, writes @wrmead. He has made himself an international outlaw and turned the great nation of Russia into a rogue state. https://t.co/JgfKpmDzEb

Some of Canada’s government-owned liquor retail monopolies are pulling Russian products, mostly vodka, off their shelves in response to the country’s military attack on Ukraine https://t.co/SKX6dYFPNb

The U.S. on Friday sanctioned President Vladimir Putin of Russia as part of a broad range of new measures that the Biden administration is preparing in hopes of inflicting financial pain on Moscow after Russia invaded Ukraine https://t.co/bRPz75tTmr

The European Broadcasting Union has banned Russia from participating in this year’s popular Eurovision song contest after other nations objected to its inclusion amid its attack on Ukraine https://t.co/vHHSES1Kcv

A missile hit a commercial oil tanker while it was in international waters in the Black Sea, Moldova authorities said. The vessel caught fire after the missile strike, and the ship's crew abandoned the vessel with life preservers. https://t.co/eQmBdmvCRG
Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has returned war to Europe. Western officials are smarting over how they misread Putin’s intentions. “It was strategic narcissism.” https://t.co/JmssquWVS3

Shortages of oil, gas and other commodities triggered by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine will likely exacerbate inflation as central banks are trying to tame it #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/uHkzYrAzbX https://t.co/ZTUnQAQOuS
The White House warned that Kyiv could fall as Russian forces continue to advance on the city https://t.co/RCTBtznmci

The U.S. will sanction Russian President Vladimir Putin, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and members of Russia's national security team, White House press secretary Jen Psaki said https://t.co/eYZd2XTV52

Russia said it would begin restricting access to Facebook for “violating basic rights and freedoms” of Russian citizens, after the U.S. social media platform allegedly moved to block the pages of four Russian media outlets https://t.co/8zcXPbk7VT

Russia invaded Ukraine to start the biggest land war in Europe since Hitler. U.S. stocks soared. What gives? Expect markets to keep swinging about as reality intrudes, says columnist @jmackin2. https://t.co/K0YqeGcubn
Oklahoma Sen. Jim Inhofe, the top Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, is expected to retire after almost three decades in the Senate https://t.co/r20DNsy3SE

The British government is pressuring oil giant BP to offload its minority stake in Russian oil company PAO Rosneft, citing the Russian oil giant’s links to the Kremlin and accusing Rosneft of fueling the Russian army’s advance into Ukraine https://t.co/jkof3sPmwr
Essay: Ukraine rose up 8 years ago, forging a new civic bond and commitment. Its people are preparing to fight for what they built, writes Marci Shore. https://t.co/34AMYLa9q7
From @WSJopinion: The only sanctions that will really get Putin’s attention are those that threaten his control of Russia and the loyalty of his cronies https://t.co/wja6DFPcbe

The Ukrainian resistance against the Russian invasion is stronger than the U.S. first expected and has so far blunted the attack on Kyiv, as the Russians are landing an amphibious force near the city of Mariupol on the Sea of Azov, an official said https://t.co/ymT86ierrl
Verizon said it will waive calling charges to and from Ukraine from Friday through March 10 https://t.co/U5sUNp1UQt
The state-owned National Bank of Pakistan agreed to pay $55.4 million to U.S. regulators over compliance deficiencies at its New York branch https://t.co/yDWKXnymYR

Despite Russia signaling openness to holding talks with the Ukrainian government, Vladimir Putin verbally attacked President Volodymyr Zelensky and his government, comparing them to terrorists https://t.co/euUalVoG9i

From @WSJopinion: We may be about to witness the largest land war in Europe since 1945, writes @KarlRove. Can America still lead with the strength and determination the world needs? https://t.co/NHesuEi8IR
